data.title: Hugh Oâ€™Brian, actor who played Wyatt Earp, dies at 91
data.meta_description: Hugh O'Brian, who helped tame the Wild West as the star of TV's 'The Life and Legend of Wyatt Earp,' has died. He was 91.
data.text:
Hugh Oâ€™Brian, who helped tame the Wild West as the star of TVâ€™s â€œThe Life and Legend of Wyatt Earpâ€ and was the founder of a long-running youth leadership development organization, has died. He was 91.

Oâ€™Brian, who had several health issues, died Monday morning with his wife nearby at their Beverly Hills home, his publicist Harlan Boll said.

Handsome, square-jawed and athletically fit, the dark-haired Oâ€™Brian appeared in a string of movies and TV anthology series in the years before he became a star portraying the real-life Old West peace officer on â€œThe Life and Legend of Wyatt Earp,â€ which ran on ABC from 1955 to 1961.

TVâ€™s first adult western, â€œWyatt Earpâ€ became a top 10-rated series and made Oâ€™Brian a household name.

Portraying what the showâ€™s theme song described as the â€œbrave, courageous and boldâ€ frontier lawman, Oâ€™Brian wore a black frock coat, a gold brocade vest, a string tie and a flat-brimmed black hat â€” and he kept the peace with the help of a â€œBuntline Specialâ€: a .45 revolver with an extra-long barrel.

In portraying Earp, Oâ€™Brian became known for his fast draw.

â€œI didnâ€™t want to force them into having to cut away whenever that happened; I wanted it to be realistic,â€ the actor said in a 2005 â€œArchive of American Televisionâ€ interview.

He spent hundreds of hours practicing the quick draw, the result of which, he said, â€œbecame a very big promotional tool ... and everybody talked about the quick draw.â€

During the seriesâ€™ run, Oâ€™Brian received an Emmy nomination and became so identified with his dead-shot TV character that he did his best to keep the name Oâ€™Brian separated from Earp.

He did it by doing a lot of outside acting â€” on anthology series such as â€œPlayhouse 90â€ and â€œDesilu Playhouseâ€ â€” as well as guest appearances on TV variety shows and a stint on Broadway starring in the musical comedy â€œDestry Rides Again.â€

Decades later, Oâ€™Brian showed up as Earp in two 1989 episodes of the TV western â€œParadise.â€ He also appeared as Earp in the 1991 Kenny Rogers TV miniseries â€œThe Gambler Returns: The Luck of the Drawâ€. And he starred in â€œWyatt Earp: Return to Tombstone,â€ a 1994 TV movie that included flashbacks to scenes from his old series.

As Oâ€™Brian once said of the TV western that made him a star: â€œItâ€™s been a great horse, and she keeps coming around the corral.â€

Among his post-â€Wyatt Earpâ€ movie credits were â€œCome Fly With Me,â€ â€œAfrica â€” Texas Style,â€ â€œThe Shootistâ€ and â€œTwins.â€ He also starred in the 1972-73 NBC adventure series â€œSearch,â€ did more stage work and made guest appearances on series such as â€œFantasy Islandâ€ and â€œThe Love Boat.â€

But Oâ€™Brianâ€™s most enduring legacy is off-screen.

More than 375,000 high school sophomores selected by their schools have gone through his Hugh Oâ€™Brian Youth Leadership organization, which was founded â€œto inspire and develop our global community of youth and volunteers to a life dedicated to leadership, service and innovation.â€

The nonprofit organization grew out of an invitation to Oâ€™Brian from Dr. Albert Schweitzer to visit the medical missionary, a 1952 Nobel Peace Prize recipient, at his famed hospital in Africa.

Oâ€™Brian spent nine days working as a volunteer at the hospital on the banks of the Ogooue River in Gabon during the summer of 1958.

For Oâ€™Brian, it was a life-changing experience.

After dinner each evening, he and Schweitzer would spend hours talking.

As Oâ€™Brian was getting ready to depart down river, he later recalled, Schweitzer took his hand and asked, â€œHugh, what are you going to do with this?â€

On his flight back to the United States, Oâ€™Brian reflected on Schweitzerâ€™s comment that â€œthe most important part of education is teaching young people to think for themselves.â€

â€œWhile the entertainment industry has lost one of its own and the baby boomers have lost their Wyatt Earp,â€ a statement on the HOBY website said Monday, â€œwe will remember Hugh as a person who dedicated his life to inspiring a global community of youth and volunteers committed to leadership, service and innovation.â€

Oâ€™Brian was born Hugh Krampe in Rochester, N.Y., on April 19, 1925. He enlisted in the Marine Corps in 1943 and was assigned as a drill instructor in San Diego.

With hopes of becoming a lawyer, Oâ€™Brian was scheduled to begin attending Yale University on the G.I. Bill in the fall of 1947. He spent the spring and summer in Los Angeles, working to earn enough money to buy a car to drive East, but had an unexpected change of plans when the actress he was dating began rehearsals for the Somerset Maugham play â€œHome and Beautyâ€ at the Wilshire Ebell Theatre.

â€œIf I wanted to see her, I had to go to rehearsals,â€ he recalled in a 2009 interview with The Times.

When the leading man didnâ€™t show up on the second or third night of rehearsals, Oâ€™Brian was asked to read the leading manâ€™s role.

â€œAfter about four days, they realized the guy wasnâ€™t going to come back ... so the director asked me if I would do the role.... We did the show and a reporter for the L.A. Times came down to see it and the next day, he wrote a tremendous review ... Thatâ€™s how I got started.â€

The showâ€™s playbill, however, misspelled his name.

â€œThey left the â€˜mâ€™ out of Krampe,â€™â€œ he said in a 2013 Times interview. â€œI decided right then I didnâ€™t want to go through life being known as Huge Krape, so I decided to take my motherâ€™s family name, Oâ€™Brien. But they misspelled it as â€˜Oâ€™Brianâ€™ and I just decided to stay with that.â€

A third-billed starring role as a wheelchair-bound paraplegic in the Ida Lupino-directed 1950 movie drama â€œNever Fearâ€ marked what Oâ€™Brian later described as his â€œreal beginningâ€ as an actor. A contract with Universal followed.

Oâ€™Brian was a one of the founders of the Thalians, a show-business charitable organization formed in 1955 to raise money for children with mental health problems. In 1964, he established the Hugh Oâ€™Brian Acting Awards competition at UCLA.

In 2006, Oâ€™Brian married for the first time.

In what was described as â€œthe wedding to die for,â€ he and his longtime girlfriend, the former Virginia Barber, were married at Forest Lawn Memorial-Park in Glendale.

Oâ€™Brian is survived by his wife, Virginia, brother Don Krampe and seven nieces and nephews.

McLellan is a former Times staff writer.

1:45 p.m.: This article was updated with confirmation of Oâ€™Brianâ€™s death by his publicist.
